Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded gym, clutching my voter registration card, eyes darting between the two lines. The official’s voice echoed, “A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with B, so I hesitated, glancing at the new, longer line. I wanted to follow the rules, but the original line was moving so much faster. My phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a text from Mom: “Can you call? Dad’s having a hard day.” I knew what that meant—she needed me, needed my calm words and steady presence. I felt the weight of her expectation, the way she leaned on me when things got tough at home. But here, I was a voter, expected to obey the officials, to do my civic duty properly. My heart pounded as I shuffled forward, torn between the urge to step out and call my parents, and the pressure to stay in line and follow the instructions. The two roles pulled at me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
